articles.headline: Trial Offers Rare Look at Work of Hezbollah in Europe
articles.snippet: Hossam Taleb Yaacoub said he staked out locations frequented by Israelis in Cyprus and acted as a courier for Hezbollah inside the European Union.
articles.abstract: Hossam Taleb Yaacoub said he staked out locations frequented by Israelis in Cyprus and acted as a courier for Hezbollah inside the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — In a little-noticed trial in a small courtroom here on Wednesday, a 24-year-old man provided a rare look inside a covert global war between Israel and Iran, admitting that he is an operative of the militant group Hezbollah, for which he acted as a courier in Europe and staked out locations in this port city that Israelis were known to frequent.

articles.headline: Big Sensor, Small Body: A Concept That Works
articles.snippet: Sony introduces the RX1, the first compact full-frame camera. But “compact” and “full frame” can’t coexist, or can they?
articles.abstract: Sony introduces the RX1, the first compact full-frame camera. But “compact” and “full frame” can’t coexist, or can they?
articles.lead_paragraph: When you’re shopping for a camera, you have a million specs and features to consider. Size, weight, battery life, megapixels, zoom power. ... Can you guess which aspect consumers consider most important?

articles.headline: Quel Brouhaha! A Diatribe on Unions Irks the French
articles.snippet: An American executive delivered a broadside as he rejected France’s plea to take over a Goodyear plant scheduled for closure.
articles.abstract: An American executive delivered a broadside as he rejected France’s plea to take over a Goodyear plant scheduled for closure.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — “How stupid do you think we are?”

articles.headline: Boeing to Propose Redesign of 787 Battery to F.A.A.
articles.snippet: A top executive will meet with agency officials on Friday to outline efforts to get the Boeing 787 back in the air.
articles.abstract: A top executive will meet with agency officials on Friday to outline efforts to get the Boeing 787 back in the air.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing has developed possible fixes for the battery problems in its grounded 787 jets and could have them back in the air within two months, industry and federal officials said Wednesday.

articles.headline: With PlayStation 4, Sony Aims for Return to Glory
articles.snippet: Sony held a gathering in New York City to introduce its new PlayStation, but it did not unveil the console and did not say when it would go on sale.
articles.abstract: Sony held a gathering in New York City to introduce its new PlayStation, but it did not unveil the console and did not say when it would go on sale.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the Sony Corporation, a tech industry also-ran, the moment of reckoning is here.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and David Streitfeld

articles.headline:
G.O.P. Is Resisting
Obama Pressure on
Tax Increase
articles.snippet: House Republicans have dug in against President Obama’s proposals to avert $85 billion in wide spending reductions set for March 1, believing they hold the upper hand in this fight.
articles.abstract: House Republicans have dug in against President Obama’s proposals to avert $85 billion in wide spending reductions set for March 1, believing they hold the upper hand in this fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans, shrugging off rising pressure from President Obama, are resolutely opposing new tax increases to head off $85 billion in across-the-board spending reductions, all but ensuring the cuts will go into force March 1 and probably remain in place for months, if not longer.

articles.headline: Budget Cuts Seen as Risk to Growth of U.S. Economy
articles.snippet: The cuts could reduce growth by about one-half of a percentage point in 2013, according to a range of government and private forecasters.
articles.abstract: The cuts could reduce growth by about one-half of a percentage point in 2013, according to a range of government and private forecasters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fresh round of federal spending cuts scheduled to begin next week would slow economic growth in the next year, though not nearly as much as going over the so-called fiscal cliff might have, economists said.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Annie Lowrey

articles.headline: Google Searches for Style
articles.snippet: As Google and other companies begin to build wearable technology devices, an industry not known for its fashion sense faces a new challenge.
articles.abstract: As Google and other companies begin to build wearable technology devices, an industry not known for its fashion sense faces a new challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: People wearing Google’s glasses are transported to a strange new world in which the Internet is always in their line of sight. But for people looking at the people wearing those glasses, the view is even stranger — someone wearing a computer processor, a battery and a tiny screen on her face.

articles.headline: Some Victims of Online Hacking Edge Into the Light
articles.snippet: Few American corporations that have been hacked in recent years have publicly acknowledged it, but some are now stepping forward, reflecting new ways of judging such disclosures.
articles.abstract: Few American corporations that have been hacked in recent years have publicly acknowledged it, but some are now stepping forward, reflecting new ways of judging such disclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers have hit thousands of American corporations in the last few years, but few companies ever publicly admit it. Most treat online attacks as a dirty secret best kept from customers, shareholders and competitors, lest the disclosure sink their stock price and tarnish them as hapless.

articles.headline: White House Tactic for C.I.A. Bid Holds Back Drone Memos
articles.snippet: The White House may deny Democrats information on targeted killings but tell Republicans more about an attack in Libya to win confirmation for John O. Brennan.
articles.abstract: The White House may deny Democrats information on targeted killings but tell Republicans more about an attack in Libya to win confirmation for John O. Brennan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is refusing to share fully with Congress the legal opinions that justify targeted killings, while maneuvering to make sure its stance does not do anything to endanger the confirmation of John O. Brennan as C.I.A. director.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Routed by Katrina, Stuck in Quagmire of Rules
articles.snippet: As people in the Northeast set off on the road back from Hurricane Sandy, Errol Joseph sees his story in New Orleans as a cautionary tale.
articles.abstract: As people in the Northeast set off on the road back from Hurricane Sandy, Errol Joseph sees his story in New Orleans as a cautionary tale.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Errol Joseph has the doorknobs. He has the doors, too, as well as a bathtub and a couple of sinks, stacks of drywall, a hot water heater, pipes, an air-conditioner compressor, and big pink rolls of insulation. They are sitting in a shed.
